column4: Anybody have any ideas what's going on here: http://pastie.org/1129999
I swear I did nothing to provoke this.
any thoughts on how to deal with gdebi being borked? It seems that a bunch of my programs now no longer work, and I have no idea why this is or what happened.
The "Input/output error" error is important.  Before making any more package changes, look at your /var/log/messages file for disk problems.
Yeah, Input/Output errors don't bode well, but I'm not seeing any errors in /var/log/messages...
At least not any obvious ones...
`cd /var/cache/apt/archives` and `dpkg --install` the gdebi packages manually.
Hrm...I already did apt-get clean...I'm guessing there will be no cache...
The front-end tools like apt and aptitude are stuck until you get the bad gdebi package reinstalled.   Do an `apt-get install --reinstall gdebi` to get the package, and do the dpkg afterwards.
Hrmm...I tried that, but I'm not seeing anything in /var/cache/apt/archives
apt-get should download the deb to /var/cache/apt/archives.  If it isn't there, then you have another problem.
Hm. Perhaps I have another problem. The only things I see there are an empty directory called "partial" and a file called "lock"
If the packaging system is broken, then don't use any of the fancy front ends.  Use only dpkg and apt until the packaging system is repaired.
On a related (?) note, it seems all the mono apps on my system won't start...which is interesting.
can you help me with using those?
Pastebin verbose apt-get output.
for what command? Just apt-get?
I'm out of time.  Somebody else might help you.
OK, thanks anyway for the help. I'll continue poking around until I can get this thing working again....ugh.

Assuming that your hardware is good and your filesystem is intact, the solution for packaging failures like this is usually `dpkg --purge --force MyBadPackage` followed by a manual `dpkg --install MyBadPackage.deb`.
Hrmm...unknown force option 'gdebi'
`man dpkg` and search for the appropriate --force-* option.  There are several.
Yeah...I'm looking into that now...
Hmmm...this is VERY suspicious: Another I/O problem: http://pastie.org/1130070
